Title: An adversary may gain unauthorized access to Web API due to poor access control checks
Description: An adversary may gain unauthorized access to Web API due to poor access control checks
Possible Mitigation(s): Implement proper authorization mechanism in ASP.NET Web API. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#authz-aspnet&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#authz-aspnet&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive information from an API through error messages
Description: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data such as the following, through verbose error messages - Server names - Connection strings - Usernames - Passwords - SQL procedures - Details of dynamic SQL failures - Stack trace and lines of code - Variables stored in memory - Drive and folder locations - Application install points - Host configuration settings - Other internal application details
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that proper exception handling is done in ASP.NET Web API. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#exception&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#exception&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data by sniffing traffic to Web API
Description: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data by sniffing traffic to Web API
Possible Mitigation(s): Force all traffic to Web APIs over HTTPS connection. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#webapi-https&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#webapi-https&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data stored in Web API's config files
Description: An adversary can gain access to the config files. and if sensitive data is stored in it, it would be compromised.
Possible Mitigation(s): Encrypt sections of Web API&#39;s configuration files that contain sensitive data. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#config-sensitive&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#config-sensitive&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: Attacker can deny a malicious act on an API leading to repudiation issues
Description: Attacker can deny a malicious act on an API leading to repudiation issues
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that auditing and logging is enforced on Web API. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#logging-web-api&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#logging-web-api&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary may spoof Mango Web Application and gain access to Web API
Description: If proper authentication is not in place, an adversary can spoof a source process or external entity and gain unauthorized access to the Web Application
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that standard authentication techniques are used to secure Web APIs. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#authn-secure-api&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#authn-secure-api&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary may inject malicious inputs into an API and affect downstream processes
Description: An adversary may inject malicious inputs into an API and affect downstream processes
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that model validation is done on Web API methods. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#validation-api&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#validation-api&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Implement input validation on all string type parameters accepted by Web API methods. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#string-api&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#string-api&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data by performing SQL injection through Web API
Description: SQL injection is an attack in which malicious code is inserted into strings that are later passed to an instance of SQL Server for parsing and execution. The primary form of SQL injection consists of direct insertion of code into user-input variables that are concatenated with SQL commands and executed. A less direct attack injects malicious code into strings that are destined for storage in a table or as metadata. When the stored strings are subsequently concatenated into a dynamic SQL command, the malicious code is executed.
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that type-safe parameters are used in Web API for data access. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#typesafe-api&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#typesafe-api&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can reverse weakly encrypted or hashed content
Description: An adversary can reverse weakly encrypted or hashed content
Possible Mitigation(s): Do not expose security details in error messages. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#messages&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#messages&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Implement Default error handling page. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#default&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#default&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Set Deployment Method to Retail in IIS. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#deployment&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#deployment&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Use only approved symmetric block ciphers and key lengths. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#cipher-length&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#cipher-length&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Use approved block cipher modes and initialization vectors for symmetric ciphers. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#vector-ciphers&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#vector-ciphers&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Use approved asymmetric algorithms, key lengths, and padding. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#padding&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#padding&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Use approved random number generators. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#numgen&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#numgen&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Do not use symmetric stream ciphers. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#stream-ciphers&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#stream-ciphers&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Use approved MAC/HMAC/keyed hash algorithms. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#mac-hash&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#mac-hash&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Use only approved cryptographic hash functions. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#hash-functions&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#hash-functions&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Verify X.509 certificates used to authenticate SSL, TLS, and DTLS connections. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#x509-ssltls&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#x509-ssltls&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary may gain access to sensitive data from log files
Description: An adversary may gain access to sensitive data from log files
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that the application does not log sensitive user data. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#log-sensitive-data&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#log-sensitive-data&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that Audit and Log Files have Restricted Access. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#log-restricted-access&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#log-restricted-access&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive information through error messages
Description: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data such as the following, through verbose error messages - Server names  - Connection strings  - Usernames  - Passwords  - SQL procedures  - Details of dynamic SQL failures  - Stack trace and lines of code  - Variables stored in memory  - Drive and folder locations  - Application install points  - Host configuration settings  - Other internal application details
Possible Mitigation(s): Do not expose security details in error messages. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#messages&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#messages&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Implement Default error handling page. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#default&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#default&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Set Deployment Method to Retail in IIS. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#deployment&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#deployment&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Exceptions should fail safely. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#fail&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#fail&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; ASP.NET applications must disable tracing and debugging prior to deployment. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#trace-deploy&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#trace-deploy&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Implement controls to prevent username enumeration. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#controls-username-enum&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#controls-username-enum&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: Attacker can deny the malicious act and remove the attack foot prints leading to repudiation issues
Description: Proper logging of all security events and user actions builds traceability in a system and denies any possible repudiation issues. In the absence of proper auditing and logging controls, it would become impossible to implement any accountability in a system
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that auditing and logging is enforced on the application. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#auditing&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#auditing&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that log rotation and separation are in place. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#log-rotation&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#log-rotation&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that Audit and Log Files have Restricted Access. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#log-restricted-access&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#log-restricted-access&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that User Management Events are Logged. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#user-management&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#user-management&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can spoof the target web application due to insecure TLS certificate configuration
Description: Ensure that TLS certificate parameters are configured with correct values
Possible Mitigation(s): Verify X.509 certificates used to authenticate SSL, TLS, and DTLS connections. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#x509-ssltls&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#x509-ssltls&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can steal sensitive data like user credentials
Description: Attackers can exploit weaknesses in system to steal user credentials. Downstream and upstream components are often accessed by using credentials stored in configuration stores. Attackers may steal the upstream or downstream component credentials. Attackers may steal credentials if, Credentials are stored and sent in clear text, Weak input validation coupled with dynamic sql queries, Password retrieval mechanism are poor,
Possible Mitigation(s): Explicitly disable the autocomplete HTML attribute in sensitive forms and inputs. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtdata#autocomplete-input&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtdata#autocomplete-input&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Perform input validation and filtering on all string type Model properties. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#typemodel&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#typemodel&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Validate all redirects within the application are closed or done safely. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#redirect-safe&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#redirect-safe&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Enable step up or adaptive authentication. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#step-up-adaptive-authn&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#step-up-adaptive-authn&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Implement forgot password functionalities securely. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#forgot-pword-fxn&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#forgot-pword-fxn&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that password and account policy are implemented. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#pword-account-policy&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#pword-account-policy&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Implement input validation on all string type parameters accepted by Controller methods. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#string-method&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#string-method&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can create a fake website and launch phishing attacks
Description: Phishing is attempted to obtain sensitive information such as usernames, passwords, and credit card details (and sometimes, indirectly, money), often for malicious reasons, by masquerading as a Web Server which is a trustworthy entity in electronic communication
Possible Mitigation(s): Verify X.509 certificates used to authenticate SSL, TLS, and DTLS connections. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#x509-ssltls&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#x509-ssltls&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that authenticated ASP.NET pages incorporate UI Redressing or clickjacking defences. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#ui-defenses&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#ui-defenses&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Validate all redirects within the application are closed or done safely. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#redirect-safe&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#redirect-safe&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can gain unauthorized access to database due to lack of network access protection
Description: If there is no restriction at network or host firewall level, to access the database then anyone can attempt to connect to the database from an unauthorized location
Possible Mitigation(s): Configure a Windows Firewall for Database Engine Access. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#firewall-db

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data stored in Web App's config files
Description: An adversary can gain access to the config files. and if sensitive data is stored in it, it would be compromised.
Possible Mitigation(s): Encrypt sections of Web App&#39;s configuration files that contain sensitive data. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtdata#encrypt-data&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtdata#encrypt-data&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can perform action on behalf of other user due to lack of controls against cross domain requests
Description: Failure to restrict requests originating from third party domains may result in unauthorized actions or access of data
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that authenticated ASP.NET pages incorporate UI Redressing or clickjacking defences. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#ui-defenses&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#ui-defenses&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that only trusted origins are allowed if CORS is enabled on ASP.NET Web Applications. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#cors-aspnet&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#cors-aspnet&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Mitigate against Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) attacks on ASP.NET web pages. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtsmgmt#csrf-asp&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtsmgmt#csrf-asp&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary may bypass critical steps or perform actions on behalf of other users (victims) due to improper validation logic
Description: Failure to restrict the privileges and access rights to the application to individuals who require the privileges or access rights may result into unauthorized use of data due to inappropriate rights settings and validation.
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that administrative interfaces are appropriately locked down. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#admin-interface-lockdown&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#admin-interface-lockdown&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Enforce sequential step order when processing business logic flows. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#sequential-logic&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#sequential-logic&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that proper authorization is in place and principle of least privileges is followed. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#principle-least-privilege&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#principle-least-privilege&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Business logic and resource access authorization decisions should not be based on incoming request parameters. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#logic-request-parameters&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#logic-request-parameters&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that content and resources are not enumerable or accessible via forceful browsing. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#enumerable-browsing&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#enumerable-browsing&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can reverse weakly encrypted or hashed content
Description: An adversary can reverse weakly encrypted or hashed content
Possible Mitigation(s): Do not expose security details in error messages. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#messages&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#messages&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Implement Default error handling page. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#default&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#default&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Set Deployment Method to Retail in IIS. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#deployment&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#deployment&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Use only approved symmetric block ciphers and key lengths. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#cipher-length&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#cipher-length&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Use approved block cipher modes and initialization vectors for symmetric ciphers. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#vector-ciphers&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#vector-ciphers&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Use approved asymmetric algorithms, key lengths, and padding. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#padding&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#padding&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Use approved random number generators. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#numgen&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#numgen&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Do not use symmetric stream ciphers. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#stream-ciphers&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#stream-ciphers&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Use approved MAC/HMAC/keyed hash algorithms. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#mac-hash&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#mac-hash&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Use only approved cryptographic hash functions. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#hash-functions&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#hash-functions&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Verify X.509 certificates used to authenticate SSL, TLS, and DTLS connections. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#x509-ssltls&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#x509-ssltls&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary may gain access to sensitive data from log files
Description: An adversary may gain access to sensitive data from log files
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that the application does not log sensitive user data. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#log-sensitive-data&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#log-sensitive-data&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that Audit and Log Files have Restricted Access. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#log-restricted-access&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#log-restricted-access&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can spoof the target web application due to insecure TLS certificate configuration
Description: Ensure that TLS certificate parameters are configured with correct values
Possible Mitigation(s): Verify X.509 certificates used to authenticate SSL, TLS, and DTLS connections. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#x509-ssltls&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#x509-ssltls&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Description: Attackers can exploit weaknesses in system to steal user credentials. Downstream and upstream components are often accessed by using credentials stored in configuration stores. Attackers may steal the upstream or downstream component credentials. Attackers may steal credentials if, Credentials are stored and sent in clear text, Weak input validation coupled with dynamic sql queries, Password retrieval mechanism are poor,
Possible Mitigation(s): Explicitly disable the autocomplete HTML attribute in sensitive forms and inputs. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtdata#autocomplete-input&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtdata#autocomplete-input&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Perform input validation and filtering on all string type Model properties. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#typemodel&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#typemodel&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Validate all redirects within the application are closed or done safely. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#redirect-safe&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#redirect-safe&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Enable step up or adaptive authentication. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#step-up-adaptive-authn&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#step-up-adaptive-authn&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Implement forgot password functionalities securely. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#forgot-pword-fxn&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#forgot-pword-fxn&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that password and account policy are implemented. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#pword-account-policy&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#pword-account-policy&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Implement input validation on all string type parameters accepted by Controller methods. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#string-method&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#string-method&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data by performing SQL injection through Web API
Description: SQL injection is an attack in which malicious code is inserted into strings that are later passed to an instance of SQL Server for parsing and execution. The primary form of SQL injection consists of direct insertion of code into user-input variables that are concatenated with SQL commands and executed. A less direct attack injects malicious code into strings that are destined for storage in a table or as metadata. When the stored strings are subsequently concatenated into a dynamic SQL command, the malicious code is executed.
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that type-safe parameters are used in Web API for data access. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#typesafe-api

Title: An adversary can reverse engineer and tamper binaries
Description: An adversary can use various tools, reverse engineer binaries and abuse them by tampering
Possible Mitigation(s): Obfuscate generated binaries before distributing to end users. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtdata#binaries-end

Title: An adversary may inject malicious inputs into an API and affect downstream processes
Description: An adversary may inject malicious inputs into an API and affect downstream processes
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that model validation is done on Web API methods. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#validation-api Implement input validation on all string type parameters accepted by Web API methods. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#string-api

Title: An adversary may spoof Mobile App (IOS, Android) and gain access to Web API
Description: If proper authentication is not in place, an adversary can spoof a source process or external entity and gain unauthorized access to the Web Application
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that standard authentication techniques are used to secure Web APIs. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#authn-secure-api

Title: An adversary obtains refresh or access tokens from Mobile App (IOS, Android) and uses them to obtain access to the Mango Web API API
Description: On a public client (e.g. a mobile device), refresh tokens may be stolen and used by an attacker to obtain access to the API. Depending on the client type, there are different ways that tokens may be revealed to an attacker and therefore different ways to protect them, some involving how the software using the tokens requests, stores and refreshes them.
Possible Mitigation(s): Use ADAL libraries to manage token requests from OAuth2 clients to AAD (or on-premises AD). Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#adal-oauth2

Title: Attacker can deny a malicious act on an API leading to repudiation issues
Description: Attacker can deny a malicious act on an API leading to repudiation issues
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that auditing and logging is enforced on Web API. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#logging-web-api

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data stored in Web API's config files
Description: An adversary can gain access to the config files. and if sensitive data is stored in it, it would be compromised.
Possible Mitigation(s): Encrypt sections of Web API's configuration files that contain sensitive data. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#config-sensitive

Title: An adversary can gain sensitive data from mobile device
Description: If application saves sensitive PII or HBI data on phone SD card or local storage, then it ay get stolen.
Possible Mitigation(s): Encrypt sensitive or PII data written to phones local storage. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtdata#pii-phones

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data by sniffing traffic to Web API
Description: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data by sniffing traffic to Web API
Possible Mitigation(s): Force all traffic to Web APIs over HTTPS connection. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#webapi-https

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data by sniffing traffic from Mobile client
Description: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data by sniffing traffic from Mobile client
Possible Mitigation(s): Implement Certificate Pinning. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#cert-pinning

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive information from an API through error messages
Description: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data such as the following, through verbose error messages - Server names - Connection strings - Usernames - Passwords - SQL procedures - Details of dynamic SQL failures - Stack trace and lines of code - Variables stored in memory - Drive and folder locations - Application install points - Host configuration settings - Other internal application details
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that proper exception handling is done in ASP.NET Web API. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#exception

Title: An adversary may gain unauthorized access to Web API due to poor access control checks
Description: An adversary may gain unauthorized access to Web API due to poor access control checks
Possible Mitigation(s): Implement proper authorization mechanism in ASP.NET Web API. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#authz-aspnet

Title: An adversary may jail break into a mobile device and gain elevated privileges
Description: An adversary may jail break into a mobile device and gain elevated privileges
Possible Mitigation(s): Implement implicit jailbreak or rooting detection. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#rooting-detection

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data stored in Web App's config files
Description: An adversary can gain access to the config files. and if sensitive data is stored in it, it would be compromised.
Possible Mitigation(s): Encrypt sections of Web App's configuration files that contain sensitive data. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtdata#encrypt-data

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data by performing SQL injection through Web App
Description: SQL injection is an attack in which malicious code is inserted into strings that are later passed to an instance of SQL Server for parsing and execution. The primary form of SQL injection consists of direct insertion of code into user-input variables that are concatenated with SQL commands and executed. A less direct attack injects malicious code into strings that are destined for storage in a table or as metadata. When the stored strings are subsequently concatenated into a dynamic SQL command, the malicious code is executed.
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that type-safe parameters are used in Web Application for data access. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#typesafe

Title: An attacker steals messages off the network and replays them in order to steal a user's session
Description: An attacker steals messages off the network and replays them in order to steal a user's session

Title: An adversary can deface the target web application by injecting malicious code or uploading dangerous files
Description: Website defacement is an attack on a website where the attacker changes the visual appearance of the site or a webpage.
Possible Mitigation(s): Implement Content Security Policy (CSP), and disable inline javascript. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#csp-js Enable browser's XSS filter. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#xss-filter Access third party javascripts from trusted sources only. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#js-trusted Enable ValidateRequest attribute on ASP.NET Pages. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#validate-aspnet Ensure that each page that could contain user controllable content opts out of automatic MIME sniffing . Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#out-sniffing Use locally-hosted latest versions of JavaScript libraries . Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#local-js Ensure appropriate controls are in place when accepting files from users. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#controls-users Disable automatic MIME sniffing. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#mime-sniff Encode untrusted web output prior to rendering. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#rendering Perform input validation and filtering on all string type Model properties. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#typemodel Ensure that the system has inbuilt defences against misuse. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#inbuilt-defenses Enable HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS). Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#http-hsts Implement input validation on all string type parameters accepted by Controller methods. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#string-method Avoid using Html.Raw in Razor views. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#html-razor Sanitization should be applied on form fields that accept all characters e.g, rich text editor . Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#richtext Do not assign DOM elements to sinks that do not have inbuilt encoding . Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#inbuilt-encode

Title: An adversary may spoof Desktop Web Browser (Chrome) and gain access to Web Application
Description: If proper authentication is not in place, an adversary can spoof a source process or external entity and gain unauthorized access to the Web Application
Possible Mitigation(s): Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to authenticate to Web Application. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#standard-authn-web-app

Title: An adversary can create a fake website and launch phishing attacks
Description: Phishing is attempted to obtain sensitive information such as usernames, passwords, and credit card details (and sometimes, indirectly, money), often for malicious reasons, by masquerading as a Web Server which is a trustworthy entity in electronic communication
Possible Mitigation(s): Verify X.509 certificates used to authenticate SSL, TLS, and DTLS connections. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#x509-ssltls Ensure that authenticated ASP.NET pages incorporate UI Redressing or clickjacking defences. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#ui-defenses Validate all redirects within the application are closed or done safely. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#redirect-safe

Title: Attackers can steal user session cookies due to insecure cookie attributes
Description: The session cookies is the identifier by which the server knows the identity of current user for each incoming request. If the attacker is able to steal the user token he would be able to access all user data and perform all actions on behalf of user.
Possible Mitigation(s): Applications available over HTTPS must use secure cookies. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtsmgmt#https-secure-cookies All http based application should specify http only for cookie definition. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtsmgmt#cookie-definition

Title: An adversary can get access to a user's session due to insecure coding practices
Description: The session cookies is the identifier by which the server knows the identity of current user for each incoming request. If the attacker is able to steal the user token he would be able to access all user data and perform all actions on behalf of user.
Possible Mitigation(s): Enable ValidateRequest attribute on ASP.NET Pages. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#validate-aspnet Encode untrusted web output prior to rendering. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#rendering Avoid using Html.Raw in Razor views. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#html-razor Sanitization should be applied on form fields that accept all characters e.g, rich text editor . Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#richtext Do not assign DOM elements to sinks that do not have inbuilt encoding . Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#inbuilt-encode

Title: An adversary can get access to a user's session due to improper logout and timeout
Description: The session cookies is the identifier by which the server knows the identity of current user for each incoming request. If the attacker is able to steal the user token he would be able to access all user data and perform all actions on behalf of user.
Possible Mitigation(s): Set up session for inactivity lifetime. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtsmgmt#inactivity-lifetime Implement proper logout from the application. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtsmgmt#proper-app-logout

Title: Attacker can deny the malicious act and remove the attack foot prints leading to repudiation issues
Description: Proper logging of all security events and user actions builds traceability in a system and denies any possible repudiation issues. In the absence of proper auditing and logging controls, it would become impossible to implement any accountability in a system
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that auditing and logging is enforced on the application. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#auditing Ensure that log rotation and separation are in place. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#log-rotation Ensure that Audit and Log Files have Restricted Access. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#log-restricted-access Ensure that User Management Events are Logged. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#user-management

Title: An adversary may gain access to sensitive data from uncleared browser cache
Description: An adversary may gain access to sensitive data from uncleared browser cache
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that sensitive content is not cached on the browser. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtdata#cache-browser

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive information through error messages
Description: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data such as the following, through verbose error messages - Server names  - Connection strings  - Usernames  - Passwords  - SQL procedures  - Details of dynamic SQL failures  - Stack trace and lines of code  - Variables stored in memory  - Drive and folder locations  - Application install points  - Host configuration settings  - Other internal application details
Possible Mitigation(s): Do not expose security details in error messages. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#messages Implement Default error handling page. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#default Set Deployment Method to Retail in IIS. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#deployment Exceptions should fail safely. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtxmgmt#fail ASP.NET applications must disable tracing and debugging prior to deployment. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtconfigmgmt#trace-deploy Implement controls to prevent username enumeration. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#controls-username-enum

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data by sniffing traffic to Web Application
Description: An adversary may conduct man in the middle attack and downgrade TLS connection to clear text protocol, or forcing browser communication to pass through a proxy server that he controls. This may happen because the application may use mixed content or HTTP Strict Transport Security policy is not ensured.
Possible Mitigation(s): Applications available over HTTPS must use secure cookies. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtsmgmt#https-secure-cookies Enable HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS). Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtcommsec#http-hsts

Title: An adversary can gain access to certain pages or the site as a whole.
Description: Robots.txt is often found in your site's root directory and exists to regulate the bots that crawl your site. This is where you can grant or deny permission to all or some specific search engine robots to access certain pages or your site as a whole. The standard for this file was developed in 1994 and is known as the Robots Exclusion Standard or Robots Exclusion Protocol. Detailed info about the robots.txt protocol can be found at robotstxt.org.
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that administrative interfaces are appropriately locked down. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#admin-interface-lockdown

Title: An adversary may gain access to unmasked sensitive data such as credit card numbers
Description: An adversary may gain access to unmasked sensitive data such as credit card numbers
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that sensitive data displayed on the user screen is masked. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtdata#data-mask

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data by performing SQL injection through Web App
Description: SQL injection is an attack in which malicious code is inserted into strings that are later passed to an instance of SQL Server for parsing and execution. The primary form of SQL injection consists of direct insertion of code into user-input variables that are concatenated with SQL commands and executed. A less direct attack injects malicious code into strings that are destined for storage in a table or as metadata. When the stored strings are subsequently concatenated into a dynamic SQL command, the malicious code is executed.
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that type-safe parameters are used in Web Application for data access. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#typesafe

Title: An adversary may spoof Mango Web API and gain access to Web Application
Description: If proper authentication is not in place, an adversary can spoof a source process or external entity and gain unauthorized access to the Web Application
Possible Mitigation(s): Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to authenticate to Web Application. Refer: https://aka.ms/tmtauthn#standard-authn-web-app

Title: An adversary can gain unauthorized access to database due to loose authorization rules
Description: Database access should be configured with roles and privilege based on least privilege and need to know principle.
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that least-privileged accounts are used to connect to Database server. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#privileged-server&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#privileged-server&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Implement Row Level Security RLS to prevent tenants from accessing each others data. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#rls-tenants&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#rls-tenants&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Sysadmin role should only have valid necessary users . Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#sysadmin-users&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#sysadmin-users&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive PII or HBI data in database
Description: Additional controls like Transparent Data Encryption, Column Level Encryption, EKM etc. provide additional protection mechanism to high value PII or HBI data.
Possible Mitigation(s): Use strong encryption algorithms to encrypt data in the database. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#strong-db&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#strong-db&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that sensitive data in database columns is encrypted. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtdata#db-encrypted&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtdata#db-encrypted&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that database-level encryption (TDE) is enabled. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtdata#tde-enabled&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtdata#tde-enabled&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that database backups are encrypted. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtdata#backup&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtdata#backup&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Use SQL server EKM to protect encryption keys. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#ekm-keys&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#ekm-keys&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Use AlwaysEncrypted feature if encryption keys should not be revealed to Database engine. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#keys-engine&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#keys-engine&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can gain access to sensitive data by performing SQL injection
Description: SQL injection is an attack in which malicious code is inserted into strings that are later passed to an instance of SQL Server for parsing and execution. The primary form of SQL injection consists of direct insertion of code into user-input variables that are concatenated with SQL commands and executed. A less direct attack injects malicious code into strings that are destined for storage in a table or as metadata. When the stored strings are subsequently concatenated into a dynamic SQL command, the malicious code is executed.
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that login auditing is enabled on SQL Server. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#identify-sensitive-entities&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#identify-sensitive-entities&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Ensure that least-privileged accounts are used to connect to Database server. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#privileged-server&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauthz#privileged-server&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Enable Threat detection on Azure SQL database. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#threat-detection&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#threat-detection&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt; Do not use dynamic queries in stored procedures. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#stored-proc&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtinputval#stored-proc&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can deny actions on database due to lack of auditing
Description: Proper logging of all security events and user actions builds traceability in a system and denies any possible repudiation issues. In the absence of proper auditing and logging controls, it would become impossible to implement any accountability in a system.
Possible Mitigation(s): Ensure that login auditing is enabled on SQL Server. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#identify-sensitive-entities&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#identify-sensitive-entities&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary can tamper critical database securables and deny the action
Description: An adversary can tamper critical database securables and deny the action
Possible Mitigation(s): Add digital signature to critical database securables. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#securables-db&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtcrypto#securables-db&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;

Title: An adversary may leverage the lack of monitoring systems and trigger anomalous traffic to database
Description: An adversary may leverage the lack of intrusion detection and prevention  of anomalous database activities and  trigger anomalous traffic to database
Possible Mitigation(s): Enable Threat detection on Azure SQL database. Refer: &amp;lt;a href=&quot;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#threat-detection&quot;&amp;gt;https://aka.ms/tmtauditlog#threat-detection&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;
